Theresa May will on Thursday plough on with her attempt to pass a Brexit deal, in spite of the resignation of a senior cabinet minister and a growing clamour for the prime minister to quit.

Downing Street said the government would confirm plans to publish the Withdrawal Agreement bill, which would ratify Mrs May’s revised Brexit deal, on Friday.

But Mrs May’s fate could be determined in the next 48 hours, with senior Tory MPs preparing to move against her unless she drops plans to put the legislation to a House of Commons vote on June 7.

• Who could be next in No 10? UK Prime Minister Theresa May’s most recent initiative to break the Brexit impasse has been pronounced dead on arrival. The Times reports today that May is likely to announce her departure in the coming days. As May looks set to leave No 10 battered and bruised with little to show for it, we need to consider
who could follow her and what that could mean for the Brexit outlook.
• Boris the Redeemer? One of the most divisive characters in British politics, Boris Johnson, would be unpredictable.
He is currently the favourite to replace May, according to the bookmakers’ odds – see chart. While he holds a certain charisma that can be helpful in statesmanship, his grasp of detail seems to be less than par, to put it mildly.
As a late convert to the Brexit cause in 2016, Boris could tow the hard line on Europe and allow a hard Brexit at the end of October. However, he might have the pro-Brexit credentials to unite most of the Conservatives and pass the Withdrawal Agreement. Exactly what could happen if Boris became PM would be a coin toss, in our view.
• Who else could it be? The other names in the top five are a mixed bunch. David Lidington – May’s de facto deputy, Remainer, has previously ruled himself out – but we have all heard that before. Although he would be a safe pair of hands, he could be too similar to May and thus face the same fate. Dominic Raab – ex-Brexit secretary, Brexiteer, is popular among the eurosceptics in his party. He pushed for a hard stance when he headed the UK side of the UK-EU negotiations but was undermined by May. The hard Brexit risk would rise significantly under Raab. Further down the list, Michael Gove (Brexiteer) and Jeremy Hunt (a Remainer who changed his position after the referendum), are your run-of-the-mill centre-right Conservatives – both would probably try to avoid a hard Brexit.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Hard Brexit risk rises to 25%: With May likely to be out soon, probably to be replaced by a Brexiteer, according to the latest betting odds, the Brexit risks have shifted somewhat. As the UK has six months to sort out Brexit, and as a lot can happen between now and then, we adjust our projections modestly for now. We raise the risk of a hard Brexit to 25% from 20% and remove the chance of May’s deal from the scenarios (previously at 5%). We keep the probabilities of a customs union model (45%), Norway plus model (10%), and no Brexit (20%) unchanged. However, we note that these probabilities could change drastically in the coming weeks depending on who ends up in Downing Street and we begin to learn just what the fresh pair of legs will bring to the Brexit drama.
• Tricky parliamentary arithmetic: As May has found out, you cannot do much in British politics if you do not have parliament behind you. Whoever becomes prime minister next will face the same problem. The Conservatives in parliament do not agree on Brexit. A snap election could change the composition of parliament, but probably not in the Conservatives’ favour. With the Conservatives trailing behind opposition Labour by an average of five points in
the last 10 polls, triggering a snap election now would be irrational. A new PM would find out whether the Conservatives’ major problem is with the terms of the Withdrawal Agreement or with the leader who negotiated it.

We now expect a new Prime Minister this summer, who will have won the party ballot on a tough anti-EU message, most likely Boris Johnson. With the 31 October Article 50 TEU deadline looming, Parliament
preventing a no-deal exit and the EU almost certainly unwilling to renegotiate, the new leader will have to come up with a new Brexit plan, gain time for it (by extending or revoking Article 50) and win a mandate for it (with a snap general election or a referendum). Brexit (or rather the beginning of a transition phase) is unlikely to happen this year and even 2020 looks very ambitious under almost any scenario.

BE11:18am

After a day of angry reactions to Prime Minister May’s latest Brexit plan, there is only days remaining in her premiership. As we noted yesterday, her legacy will be as the PM who failed to live up to her promise of delivering Brexit, but, in this regard, she had inherited an impossible task given the positions of the various factions in the House of Commons.
The process to elect a new Conservative leader and PM is likely to officially begin next week, although it has unofficially been running for some time. Given the number of candidates (possibly up to 17), it will not be a quick process, although it is hoped that it will be complete by the time Parliament goes into recess at the end of July. So, after the wasted six weeks in the talks between the Conservatives and Labour, we may now be facing into another eight weeks of leadership process, followed by a potential further six weeks summer break. This leaves just six weeks to the mid-October European Council meeting, by which time the UK and the EU intended to have a firm idea of the way forward in the Brexit process. During this time, the new leader will also be displaying their Conservative vision to the party faithful in conference season and will probably have pledged to renegotiate the Brexit deal with the EU.
The bottom line here is that the upcoming leadership campaign, and its likely winner, creates significant problems in finding a way forward in the Brexit process. If a new leader goes headlong towards a “no deal”, it will be up to those who have opposed this outcome to once again use unusual parliamentary manoeuvres to block it, up to and including triggering a general election. Fasten your seatbelts once again.

Bernstein wraps up the issues:

BE11:25am

(1) Casino's parent companies (Rallye, Fonciere Euris, Finatis) are over-levered. The market value of the assets of Rallye are less than the value of its debt. That makes it insolvent in our view but historical cost accounting allows it to maintain solvent in the eyes of the auditors.

(2) Casino is paying out a dividend that is much too large for its own level of leverage. Leverage by the parent companies seems to cause inexplicable contradictions at Casino: Casino embarked on a €2.5bn asset disposal program to reduce debt, but at the same time keeps paying out ~€350m per year in dividends and buys back ~€96m of its own shares. A leveraged company, with Casino's level of cash flow generation, without such parent holding companies would in our view cut the divi, not do buy backs & prioritize paying down the debt.

(3) Casino's share price has a direct impact on the liquidity of its parent companies. Some credit lines at Rallye use Casino shares as collateral. As such, when the Casino share price drops, the amount of liquidity at Rallye shrinks.

(4) The accounts of Casino need material adjustments to properly assess the company's value. This is in our view the least discussed but most important element of this debate. Several elements of CO's deal structuring (e.g. JVs), or Casino's reporting (e.g. head office costs, Segisor loan) or adjustments to underlying (consulting & legal fees) have material implications for valuations. Upon our estimates, to value Casino France, one needs to deduct €180m from the reported French EBITDA and add €2bn to the reported French Net Debt.

BE11:28am

There are several scnearios: 1) Rallye goes into safeguard proceedings and
asks for a debt haircut; as a result, JCN may leave control and Casino’s
share price will first go down. Even if the banks cannot sell the pledged
shares, they may sell their exposure to distressed investors who will ask for a discount and then short Casino; 2) the companies above Rallye .... Fonciere Euris, owns c. 60% of Rallye. It has some
Rallye shares pledged and those dropped yesterday. They may now have
an issue there with the banks (margin calls); 3) there are some bondholders from the private placement EUR110m Jan 2022 who are challenging the covenants at Rallye, and this may have led to an ad-hoc procedure that can be disruptive, and as such the share price suspension ... ; 4) Rallye gets an additional credit line, a decent one above EUR500m , but there we do not see the need to suspend the stock; and 5) Rallye sells its stake in Casino – there, the minimum price to deleverage the whole is EUR64.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

All these measures, except for the last one, which is the least likely, are
disruptive for Casino in the short term. We believe that the most likely
scenario is for Finatis, Fonciere Euris, and Rallye to merge. This would
simplify the structure and remove some leakage but not solve the leverage issue. Our fair value is based on a SOP with a DCF (8.5% WACC, 1% terminal value for France).

BE11:41am

Presumably the intent behind the making the letter public is to rally other shareholders to the cause and apply pressure to the Board which appears to have rejected the proposal when made privately. It may achieve the purpose of catalysing a takeover offer which, we believe, has become increasingly likely as the share price has fallen and as Sterling has weakened. ValueAct’s letter sets out very clearly multiple reasons why it believes that Merlin is undervalued and with which we agree. The share price is down 3% since the IPO despite a 36% increase in EPS. We would argue the IPO was overpriced and the projected LFL growth rate has deteriorated since IPO. Nevertheless, we believe the derating has been overdone and, as ValueAct points out, they share price performance can have a negative impact on management team incentivisation and motivation for the wider employee base. ValueAct believes that that one driver of the derating has been the decline in reported return on invested capital but that management is doing the right thing in continuing to invest. We agree with this too, Merlin is an inherently capital intensive business and its growth opportunities, particularly with Legoland Parks in Asia, require material capital while pivoting the centre of gravity of the business into faster-growth markets. One day the returns will come. In a nicely-turned phrase ValueAct says it can imagine a day when “the new investment super cycle is past and the Company delivers more easily-valued current return”. Agreed, this is exactly why we are Buyers of the shares. And we agree too that then weakness in the share price is down to an excessive focus on the near term EPS multiples. A deal is possible. Merlin already has a material debt burden which will be made more apparent when the adoption of IFRS 16 highlights the level of lease liability. We imagine that the Board has concluded that the Group cannot responsibly take on more debt to support an MBO, even if ValueAct and Kirkbi (Lego) rolled over their c40% combined position. And surely any possible bidders already know about Merlin without needing the cost and disruption of a “strategic review” sale process. We doubt the board will change its mind about taking the business private, it is up to a third party to emerge and make an offer which, we believe, is more likely at the current share price and level of Sterling but unlikely overall. However, this does not undermine the strength of ValueAct’s valuation argument. Merlin’s is currently undervalued and is the Group is close to the point when the recently-increased capex investment and efficiency investments begin to pay off. For the long-term investor the current share price is an excellent entry point and we reiterate our Buy rating and 450p target price.

red i think there is a happy medium bewteen private and national. regs need to be in place and unheld and then most if not everyone can be happy

BE11:43am

The letter neatly captures the dilemma facing investors in Merlin. Although the impact of the tragic London terrorism attacks is in the rear view mirror the group is now facing cost pressures which are weighing on margins and returns.
Management is seeking to mitigate these with a £35m cost saving programme over the next 3-4 years but this won’t be enough to maintain margins in FY19 according to our analysis. Investors may feel frustrated as to why management doesn’t raise prices to compensate but instead is more focused on maintaining the long term customer value proposition.
 In addition falling returns on capital have also raised questions about whether it is new brands and locations that are underperforming or whether it is the older “cash cows” that are fading. Merlin does not disclose capital employed by division, let alone by brand so investors have been unable to clearly assess the issues and whether management is making the right decisions on capital allocation.

The recent capital raise was a positive step but won’t necessarily get the balance sheet out of the woods if Tesla cannot achieve FCF targets. So the recent reported internal memo, which seemingly called into question prior guidance, didn’t help the risk/reward calculus. The implications can be serious, since an automaker’s balance sheet is always subject to the confidence “spiral” risk. Good or bad, we think it’s important for the company to provide a more formal guidance update sooner than later. In the meantime, we’ll look at our Model 3/Y tracker & future product/FSD rollouts for clearer demand signals in an important Q2.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE12:01pm

Tesla’s AV pivot actually aligns well with our long-held industry AV/mobility views. Yet we think Tesla erred by externally targeting level-5/urban RoboTaxis next year, a claim that ultimately hurt credibility. We appreciate the culture of aiming high (which might also attract talent), but claiming L5 urban arguably masks what we think might actually be a more credible & unique Tesla AV path—platforms we’ve previously termed “AV Subs”. To be sure, we still see issues even outside of L5 RoboTaxi goals (HMI, redundancies), but we do think Tesla’s approach could fit uniquely well for AV Sub platforms in “easier” domains (i.e. middle-of-the-night, no humans, routes), platforms that could conceivably drive higher market share by introducing new services (maintenance, deliveries, swaps) and peer-to-peer sharing. We continue to view the opportunity as real & large, but Tesla needs a more tailored AV network deployment plan.

FY’19 adj. pre-tax profits of £309m and adj. diluted EPS of 52p both rose 4% beating consensus by 2%. Group adjusted operating margin was flat at 11.1% with a 10bps rise to 19.4% at Food & Beverage Solutions ex-Sucralose and a 100bps decline to 8.7% at the Primary Products division due to £10m lower commodity profits. Food & Beverage Solutions delivered 3% volume growth with 3% in North America and 15% volume growth in AsiaPacific LatAm reflecting healthy returns on Tate’s investments. Adj. FCF remains strong at £212m driving a reduction in net debt / EBITDA to 0.8x and supporting a 2.4% rise in DPS. In FY20, Tate guides to continuing progress in Food & Beverage solutions and gains from productivity initiatives to offset lower Sucralose profits leading to flat to low single-digits EPS growth in constant FX. Reiterate BUY and GBp 900 TP.

BE12:11pm

And Jefferies.

BE12:12pm

FY19 c.2% ahead on all key metrics
FY19 is ahead, with adjusted operating profit (AOP) of £305m (consensus & JEFe £300m), adjusted PBT of 309m (consensus & JEFe £303m) and adjusted EPS of 52.0p (consensus 51.1p & JEFe 50.7p). Below the EBIT line, the financing charge was in line with JEFe at £26m, JV's & Associates were slightly ahead at £30m (JEFe £29m) and the effective tax rate was lower at 21.0% (JEFe 21.5%). Net debt was £337m relative to consensus & JEFe £350m & £357m. Productivity benefits contributed a gross £25m to the bottom line.

Beat led by Sucralose
FY19 AOP was £143m in Foods & Beverage Solutions (Starch specialities & Food Systems) relative to consensus & JEFe £147m. Sucralose AOP was £61m (consensus & JEFe £54m & £55m). Primary products (bulk starches, sweeteners & commodities) AOP was £148m (consensus & JEFe £147m & £143m). Central costs were £47m relative to consensus & JEFe £48m & £44m.

Food & Beverage Solutions misses. Slower volumes in H2
Profit was ahead 3% at constant fx (JEFe +6%). Volumes in Food & Beverage Solutions (a closely-watched metric) were ahead 3% for the year but decelerated to around 2% in H2 from 4% in H1. North America was ahead 3% (same as H1), Asia Pac & LatAm 15% (16% in H1) & EMEA was down 2% (flat in H1).

Primary Products
Profits were down 11% at constant fx, which implies 15-20% down in H2 (JEFe 26% down in H2). Commodity profits, at £22m, were better than we expected (JEFe £15m). Falling soft drink volumes in the US and higher input costs both impacted profits. Tate proved more resistant to cold weather in H2 than ADM or Ingredion but slowing H2 momentum in the cash cow Division, that contributes over 40% of Group profit, is a concern for us.

Sucralose beat reflects one-offs
Sucralose profits were ahead 11% at constant fx (JEFe 1% at constant) reflecting a one-off sell-down of safety stock and a £3m one-off gain from a supply contract. Sucralose will provide a tough comp for FY20 in the context of pricing eroding by 5% in FY19.

2020 guidance muted
2020 guidance is for 'flat to single digit' EPS growth at constant fx. This compares to consensus & JEFe PBT of £312m & £315m, being a 3% increase at constant fx for JEFe.
